subject: Relationships
title: Apology: The Science of Saying Sorry
description: A micro-lesson that makes Apology: The Science of Saying Sorry usable.

hook.text: 'I'm sorry you feel that way' isn't an apology. It's a deflection in disguise. Real apologies follow specific rules.

buildup.text: Real apologies have six parts: acknowledge harm, accept fault, explain, show regret, offer repair, seek forgiveness.

discovery.text: Research shows the most critical element is accepting responsibility. Without it, the rest feels hollow.

twist.text: Over-apologizing destroys the power of apology. If you say sorry for everything, sorry means nothing.

climax.text: A real apology costs something. It requires admitting fault without excuses. That's why so few people do it well.

punchline.text: A real apology admits fault without excuses. That's why they're so rare.

quiz.question: What is the most critical element of an effective apology?
